Submodules¶

tensorgraph.cost module¶

tensorgraph.cost.accuracy(ytrue, ypred)[source]¶

ytrue and ypred is 2d

tensorgraph.cost.binary_f1(ytrue, ypred)[source]¶

ytrue and ypred is one-hot, and have to be of type int and shape [batchsize, 2] since it is binary, the values must be 0 and 1

tensorgraph.cost.binary_precision(ytrue, ypred)[source]¶

ytrue and ypred is one-hot, and have to be of type int and shape [batchsize, 2] since it is binary, the values must be 0 and 1

tensorgraph.cost.binary_recall(ytrue, ypred)[source]¶

ytrue and ypred is one-hot, and have to be of type int and shape [batchsize, 2] since it is binary, the values must be 0 and 1

tensorgraph.cost.entropy(ytrue, ypred)[source]¶
tensorgraph.cost.error(ytrue, ypred)[source]¶

ytrue and ypred is 2d

tensorgraph.cost.generalised_dice(y_true, y_pred, smooth=1.0)[source]¶

Dice Loss Cost Function, where smaller groundtruth channels is penalised more heavily y_true: tensor of shape (?, D, H, W, c)

tensorgraph.cost.mean_dice(y_true, y_pred, smooth=1.0)[source]¶

Dice Loss Cost Function, where all output channels are penalised equally y_true: tensor of shape (?, D, H, W, c)

tensorgraph.data_iterator module¶

class tensorgraph.data_iterator.DataBlocks(data_paths, train_valid_ratio=[5, 1], batchsize=32, load_func=<function np_load_func>, allow_preload=False)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.data_iterator.SimpleBlocks

This is class for processing blocks of data, whereby dataset is loaded and unloaded into memory and split into train and valid one block at a time.

Parameters:
  • data_paths (list or list of list) –

    contains list of paths for data loading, .. rubric:: example

    [f1a.npy, f1b.npy, f1c.npy] or [(f1a.npy, f1b.npy, f1c.npy), (f2a.npy, f2b.npy, f2c.npy)]

  • train_valid_ratio (list) – ratio for splitting the data into train and valid
  • load_func (function) – function for loading the data_paths, default to numpy file loader
  • allow_preload (bool) – by allowing preload, it will preload the next data block while training at the same time on the current datablock, this will reduce time but will also cost more memory.
load_file(paths, queue=None)[source]¶
Parameters:paths (list or str) – paths to be loaded
class tensorgraph.data_iterator.DataIterator(*data, **params)[source]¶

Bases: object

Parameters:fullbatch (bool) – decides if the number of examples return after every iteration should be always a full batch.
next()[source]¶

for python 2.7

class tensorgraph.data_iterator.SequentialIterator(*data, **params)[source]¶

Bases: tensorgraph.data_iterator.DataIterator

Example

when batchsize = 3 then the generated index will be [0, 1, 2], [3, 4, 5], [6, 7, 8]

Parameters:fullbatch (bool) – decides if the number of examples return after every iteration should be always a full batch.
class tensorgraph.data_iterator.SimpleBlocks(data_paths, batchsize=32, load_func=<function np_load_func>, allow_preload=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

This is class for processing blocks of data, whereby dataset is loaded and unloaded into memory one block at a time.

Parameters:
  • data_paths (list or list of list) –

    contains list of paths for data loading, .. rubric:: example

    [f1a.npy, f1b.npy, f1c.npy] or [(f1a.npy, f1b.npy, f1c.npy), (f2a.npy, f2b.npy, f2c.npy)]

  • load_func (function) – function for loading the data_paths, default to numpy file loader
  • allow_preload (bool) – by allowing preload, it will preload the next data block while training at the same time on the current datablock, this will reduce time but will also cost more memory.

Parameters:paths (list or str) – paths to be loaded

Bases: tensorgraph.data_iterator.DataIterator

Example

when batchsize = 3 step = 1 then the generated index wil be [0, 1, 2], [1, 2, 3], [2, 3, 4]

For building the graph that connects all the nodes together

  • end (list) – list of end nodes

forward propagation for test mode that builds the final tensorflow graph

tensorgraph.node module¶

class tensorgraph.node.EndNode(prev, input_merge_mode=<tensorgraph.node.NoChangeState object>)[source]¶

Bases: object

EndNode is where we want to get the output from the graph. It can be connected to a HiddenNode or a StartNode.

Parameters:
  • input_merge_mode (tensorgraph.layers.Merge) – Merge Layer for merging the multiple inputs coming into this hidden node
  • prev (list) – list of previous nodes to link to
test_fprop()[source]¶
train_fprop()[source]¶
class tensorgraph.node.HiddenNode(prev, input_merge_mode=<tensorgraph.node.Sum object>, layers=[])[source]¶

Bases: object

HiddenNode encapsulates a list of layers, it can be connected to a StartNode or another HiddenNode

Parameters:
  • input_merge_mode (tensorgraph.layers.Merge) – Merge Layer for merging the multiple inputs coming into this hidden node
  • layers (list) – the sequential layers within the node
  • prev (list) – list of previous nodes to link to

Check if the output list contains one element or a list, if contains only one element, return the element, if contains more than one element, returns the entire list.

tensorgraph.stopper module¶

class tensorgraph.stopper.EarlyStopper(max_epoch=100, epoch_look_back=None, percent_decrease=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Use for doing early stopping during training

Parameters:
  • max_epoch (int) – if the training reach the max_epoch, it stops
  • epoch_look_back (int) – the number of epoch to look to check the percent decrease in validation loss. If the percent decrease is smaller than the desired value within the number of epoch look back then it stops
  • percent_decrease (float) – between 0 to 1.0, if within the epoch_look_back and the decrease in validation error is smaller than this percentage then it stops.
continue_learning(valid_error, epoch=None)[source]¶

check if should continue learning, by default first epoch starts with 1.

Parameters:
  • valid_error (float) – validation error to be keep track by early stopper, smaller is better
  • epoch (int) – the training epoch, if not specified, the stopper will auto keep track
reset()[source]¶

Parameters:data_records – dictionary of arrs of format {‘X’: X_arr, ‘y’: y_arr, …} where first dimension of the array is the example number.

Parameters:
  • tfrecords_filename_list (list) – list of tfrecords paths
  • data_shapes (dict) – dictionary of the record name and shape example: {‘X’:[32,32], ‘y’:[10]} where the shape is the shape per image

class tensorgraph.utils.MakeTFRecords_tfdata[source]¶

Bases: object

general framework for creating and reading tfrecords using tf.data API

static make_tfrecords_from_arrs(save_path, dtypes=[<class 'numpy.float32'>, <class 'numpy.float32'>])[source]¶

Make tfrecords from numpy array (and list of string (patientnames etc.))

Parameters:
  • data_records – dictionary. contains data to be made into tfrecords. Can be numpy array.
  • save_path – string. Path to save tfrecords.
  • dtypes – list of dtype in numpy. Should have same length of data_records.
Returns:

None
static read_tensor_from_tfrecords(tfrecords_filenames, data_shape, dtypes=[tf.float32, tf.float32], batch_size=8, num_epochs=1, phase='training')[source]¶

Read tensors from numpy array (and list of string (patientnames etc.))

Parameters:
  • n_exp – total number of sample of all the tfrecords_filenames
  • tfrecords_filenames – list of tfrecords files
  • data_shape – dictionary of data shape
  • dtypes – list of dtypes in tf.
  • batch_size – integer. batch size.
  • num_epochs – integer. number of epochs.
  • phase – string. Either “training” or “validation”. To determine whether shuffle.
Returns:

trainiterator – an iterator. To be initialize later! element: dictionary of data.

Convert categorical values to numeric values

Returns:return numeric list and a categorical dictionary map
tensorgraph.utils.cat_to_one_hot(cat)[source]¶
tensorgraph.utils.desame(in_height, in_width, stride, kernel_size)[source]¶

Calculate the input height and width from output height and width for deconvolution with SAME padding

Parameters:
  • in_height (int) – input height
  • in_width (int) – input width
  • stride (tuple) – tuple of (h, w)
  • kernel_size (tuple) – tuple of (h, w)

Example

>>> out_height = ceil(in_height * float(stride[0]))
>>> out_width = ceil(in_width * float(stride[1]))
tensorgraph.utils.desame_nd(shape, stride, kernel_size)[source]¶

Calculate the input height and width from output height and width for deconvolution with SAME padding for arbitrary n dimensional image

Parameters:
  • shape (list of int) – list of dimensions of n dimensional image
  • stride (list of int) – list of same dimension as shape
  • kernel_size (list of int) – list of same dimension as shape

Example

>>> out_shape[0] = ceil(in_height * float(stride[0]))
>>> out_shape[1] = ceil(in_width * float(stride[1]))
>>> ..
tensorgraph.utils.desame_x(x, stride, kernel_size)[source]¶
tensorgraph.utils.devalid(in_height, in_width, stride, kernel_size)[source]¶

Calculate the input height and width from output height and width for deconvolution with VALID padding

Parameters:
  • in_height (int) – input height
  • in_width (int) – input width
  • stride (tuple) – tuple of (h, w)
  • kernel_size (tuple) – tuple of (h, w)

Example

>>> out_height = ceil(in_height * float(stride[0])) - 1 + kernel_size[0]
>>> out_width = ceil(in_width * float(stride[1])) - 1 + kernel_size[1]
tensorgraph.utils.devalid_nd(shape, stride, kernel_size)[source]¶

calculate the input height and width from output height and width for deconvolution with VALID padding for arbitrary n dimensional image

Parameters:
  • shape (list of int) – list of dimensions of n dimensional image
  • stride (list of int) – list of same dimension as shape
  • kernel_size (list of int) – list of same dimension as shape

Example

>>> out_shape[0] = ceil(in_height * float(stride[0])) - 1 + kernel_size[0]
>>> out_shape[1] = ceil(in_width * float(stride[1])) - 1 + kernel_size[1]
tensorgraph.utils.devalid_x(x, stride, kernel_size)[source]¶
tensorgraph.utils.get_file_from_url(save_path, origin, untar=False)[source]¶
tensorgraph.utils.make_one_hot(X, onehot_size)[source]¶

Make a one-hot version of X

Parameters:
  • X – 1d numpy with each value in X representing the class of X
  • onehot_size – length of the one hot vector
Returns:

2d numpy tensor, with each row been the onehot vector
tensorgraph.utils.put_kernels_on_grid(kernel, num_kernels, pad=1)[source]¶

Visualize conv. features as an image (mostly for the 1st layer). Place kernel into a grid, with some paddings between adjacent filters.

Parameters:
  • kernel – tensor of shape [NumKernels, Y, X, NumChannels]
  • grid_X) ((grid_Y,) – shape of the grid. Require: NumKernels == grid_Y * grid_X User is responsible of how to break into two multiples.
  • num_kernels – batchsize or number of kernels
  • pad – number of black pixels around each filter (between them)
Returns:

Tensor of shape [(Y+2*pad)*grid_Y, (X+2*pad)*grid_X, NumChannels, 1].
tensorgraph.utils.same(in_height, in_width, stride, kernel_size)[source]¶

Calculate the output dimension of an input image during pooling or convolution using padded with SAME mode

Parameters:
  • in_height (int) – input height
  • in_width (int) – input width
  • stride (tuple) – tuple of (h, w)
  • kernel_size (tuple) – tuple of (h, w)

Example

>>> pad_along_height = ((out_height - 1) * stride[0] + filter_height - in_height)
>>> pad_along_width = ((out_width - 1) * stride[1] + filter_width - in_width)
tensorgraph.utils.same_nd(shape, stride, kernel_size)[source]¶

Calculate the output dimension of an input image during pooling or convolution when padded with SAME mode for arbitrary n dimensional array.

Parameters:
  • shape (list of int) – list of dimensions of n dimensional image
  • stride (list of int) – list of same dimension as shape
  • kernel_size (list of int) – list of same dimension as shape
Returns:

return the new dimension of the image after convolve with stride and kernel_size

tensorgraph.utils.valid(in_height, in_width, stride, kernel_size)[source]¶

Describe the output dimension of an input image during pooling or convolution using padded with VALID mode

Parameters:
  • in_height (int) – input height
  • in_width (int) – input width
  • stride (tuple) – tuple of (h, w)
  • kernel_size (tuple) – tuple of (h, w)

Example

>>> pad_along_height = 0
>>> pad_along_width = 0

  • stride (list of int) – list of same dimension as shape
  • kernel_size (list of int) – list of same dimension as shape

  • stride (int) – 1 number of stride
  • kernel_size (int) – 1 number of kernel_size
